arXiv:2410.03883v1 [cs.LG] 04 Oct 2024
\addauthor

mhblue \addauthorxwmagenta \addauthornebrown

DiSK: Differentially Private Optimizer with Simplified Kalman Filter for Noise Reduction

Xinwei Zhang1 ‚ÄÉZhiqi Bu2‚Ä† ‚ÄÉBorja Balle3 ‚ÄÉMingyi Hong4 ‚ÄÉMeisam Razaviyayn1‚àó
Vahab Mirrokni5
1University of Southern California, 2Amazon, 3DeepMind, 4University of Minnesota,
5Google Research xinweiz,razaviya@usc.edu, ‚Ä†This work is not affiliated with Zhiqi Bu‚Äôs position at Amazon.
Abstract

Differential privacy (DP) offers a robust framework for safeguarding individual data privacy. To utilize DP in training modern machine learning models, differentially private optimizers have been widely used in recent years. A popular approach to privatize an optimizer is to clip the individual gradients and add sufficiently large noise to the clipped gradient. This approach led to the development of DP optimizers that have comparable performance with their non-private counterparts in fine-tuning tasks or in tasks with a small number of training parameters. However, a significant performance drop is observed when these optimizers are applied to large-scale training. This degradation stems from the substantial noise injection required to maintain DP, which disrupts the optimizer‚Äôs dynamics. This paper introduces DiSK, a novel framework designed to significantly enhance the performance of DP optimizers. DiSK employs Kalman filtering, a technique drawn from control and signal processing, to effectively denoise privatized gradients and generate progressively refined gradient estimations. To ensure practicality for large-scale training, we simplify the Kalman filtering process, minimizing its memory and computational demands. We establish theoretical privacy-utility trade-off guarantees for DiSKand demonstrate provable improvements over standard DP optimizers like DPSGD in terms of iteration complexity upper-bound. Extensive experiments across diverse tasks, including vision tasks such as CIFAR-100 and ImageNet-1k and language fine-tuning tasks such as GLUE, E2E, and DART, validate the effectiveness of DiSK. The results showcase its ability to significantly improve the performance of DP optimizers, surpassing state-of-the-art results under the same privacy constraints on several benchmarks.

1 Introduction

Data privacy has become one of the major concerns in modern machine learning systems. Differential Privacy (DP), with its rigorous mathematical foundation, offers a powerful solution. DP provides a framework for developing training algorithms that safeguard the privacy of individuals‚Äô data used to train machine learning models. Among various algorithms, Differentially Private Stochastic Gradient Descent (DPSGD) (Abadi et al., 2016) and its variants (Li et al., 2021; Yu et al., 2021; Tang et al., 2024) have emerged as popular choices for training various models, including computer vision (De et al., 2022) and language models (Bu et al., 2023; 2024). These algorithms inject noise into the training process to guarantee privacy. However, this noise injection often comes at a significant cost to model performance, limiting the widespread adoption of DP optimizers (Jayaraman & Evans, 2019). For example, (McMahan et al., 2018; De et al., 2022) observed that DP training led to a 15%percent1515\%15 % drop in model accuracy on the Reddit dataset and a 30%percent3030\%30 % drop on CIFAR-10 compared to non-private training. This challenge has limited the application of DP optimizers primarily to small models or parameter-efficient fine-tuning, as highlighted by (Li et al., 2021).

Many recent works aim to improve differentially private (DP) training performance. These include applying low-pass filters to separate gradients from noise  (Zhang et al., 2024a), injecting correlated noise with algorithms like DP-FTLR (Koloskova et al., 2023; Choquette-Choo et al., 2024), using sharpness-aware minimization for flatter loss landscapes that are less sensitive to DP noise (Park et al., 2023), adaptive clipping (Andrew et al., 2021; Lin et al., 2022; Hu et al., 2021), and model structure optimization (Bu et al., 2024; Papernot et al., 2021; De et al., 2022). However, these methods often require extra memory, lack theoretical guarantees, or have limited applicability. Therefore, there is a strong demand to design a new approach that 1) is memory and computation efficient for implementation, 2) has a theoretical guarantee, and 3) is compatible with a wide range of existing DP optimization algorithms and models. To meet this demand, we leverage the Kalman filter, a tool from control theory, to improve gradient estimates in DP optimization. We further simplify our algorithm for memory and computational efficiency, while maintaining theoretical grounding and broad compatibility with existing DP algorithms and models.

The tools in signal processing and control theory have been leveraged to design novel optimization algorithms. In the context of DP optimization, the error-feedback approach has been adopted to reduce the bias caused by the clipping operation (Zhang et al., 2024b); the low-pass and high-pass filters have been used to separate the gradient from the DP noise (Zhang et al., 2024a; Koloskova et al., 2023; Choquette-Choo et al., 2024); the low-pass spatial filter, including Gaussian and Laplace filters have been used to smooth the privatized model or gradient across dimensions (Wang et al., 2020a; 2021; Liu et al., 2022). These methods effectively improve DP optimizers‚Äô performance.

1.1 Contributions

Our approach centers on constructing a dynamic system where the gradient serves as its state. We treat the privatized gradient as a noisy observation of the true gradient within this system. By applying a Kalman filter, we obtain a more accurate estimate of the true gradient by leveraging the gradient dynamics and past estimates, thereby enhancing the performance of DP optimizers. To address the inherent inefficiency of the Kalman filter, we introduce a series of simplifications that reduce memory and computational overhead. Our main contributions can be summarized as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Algorithm Design: We introduce a novel Kalman filter-based approach designed to mitigate DP noise and enhance the performance of various DP optimizers.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Algorithm Simplification: We simplify the Kalman filtering process to significantly reduce memory and computational overhead. This simplified approach, DiSK, requires only one additional forward step and two extra optimizer states.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Theoretical Analysis: We provide theoretical analyses of DiSK, demonstrating that the algorithm is convergent. Moreover, we showed that, compared to DPSGD, DiSK improves the iteration complexity upper-bound by a constant factor.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Numerical Results: Extensive experiments across various models, datasets, and optimizers demonstrate that DiSK significantly boosts DP training performance. Specifically, under the same privacy budgets, DiSK exhibits substantial improvements in test accuracy for training-from-scratch scenarios: a notable increase from 32.4%percent32.432.4\%32.4 % to 36.9%percent36.936.9\%36.9 % on the ImageNet-1k dataset, a considerable rise from 63%percent6363\%63 % to 75%percent7575\%75 % on CIFAR-10, and a remarkable improvement from 21%percent2121\%21 % to 42%percent4242\%42 % on CIFAR-100. Furthermore, in fine-tuning tasks, DiSK demonstrates remarkable improvements: an increase from 85%percent8585\%85 % to 89%percent8989\%89 % on CIFAR-100 and an improvement from 81%percent8181\%81 % to 86%percent8686\%86 % on the GLUE dataset. These results surpass state-of-the-art DP training performance under the same privacy guarantees.

2 Preliminaries

2.1 Problem Definition & Notations

Typical training procedures require solving the empirical risk minimization (ERM) problem

minùê±‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°(F‚Å¢(ùê±)=1N‚Å¢‚àëŒæ‚ààùíüf‚Å¢(ùê±;Œæ)),subscriptùê±superscript‚Ñùùëëùêπùê±1ùëÅsubscriptùúâùíüùëìùê±ùúâ\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left(F(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{N}% \sum_{\xi\in\mathcal{D}}f(\mathbf{x};\xi)\right),roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_F ( bold_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ ‚àà caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_x ; italic_Œæ ) ) , (1)

where ùê±‚àà‚Ñùdùê±superscript‚Ñùùëë\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_x ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the optimization variable, ùíü={Œæ1,‚Ä¶,ŒæN}ùíüsubscriptùúâ1‚Ä¶subscriptùúâùëÅ\mathcal{D}=\{\xi_{1},\ldots,\xi_{N}\}caligraphic_D = { italic_Œæ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_Œæ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is the training dataset with |ùíü|=NùíüùëÅ\left\lvert\mathcal{D}\right\rvert=N| caligraphic_D | = italic_N samples, and f‚Å¢(‚ãÖ)ùëì‚ãÖf(\cdot)italic_f ( ‚ãÖ ) denotes the (possibly non-convex) loss function parameterized by ùê±ùê±\mathbf{x}bold_x and evaluated on sample Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ. For solving the above optimization problem, we rely on iterative procedures, such as SGD, where the parameters are updated over the iterations t=1,2,‚Ä¶ùë°12‚Ä¶t=1,2,\ldotsitalic_t = 1 , 2 , ‚Ä¶. Throughout the paper, we use (‚ãÖ)tsubscript‚ãÖùë°(\cdot)_{t}( ‚ãÖ ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to denote the variables at iteration tùë°titalic_t, and use ùêàdsubscriptùêàùëë\mathbf{I}_{d}bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to denote the identity matrix of dimension dùëëditalic_d.

2.2 Differentially private optimization

Let us start by recalling the definition of (œµ,Œ¥)italic-œµùõø(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_œµ , italic_Œ¥ )-Differential Privacy:

Definition 1 ((œµ,Œ¥)italic-œµùõø(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_œµ , italic_Œ¥ )-DP (Dwork & Roth, 2014))

A randomized mechanism ‚Ñ≥‚Ñ≥\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M is said to be (œµ,Œ¥)italic-œµùõø(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_œµ , italic_Œ¥ )-differentially private if for any two neighboring datasets ùíü,ùíü‚Ä≤ùíüsuperscriptùíü‚Ä≤\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (ùíü,ùíü‚Ä≤ùíüsuperscriptùíü‚Ä≤\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT differ only by one sample) and for any measurable output set ùíÆùíÆ\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S, it holds that Pr‚Å¢[‚Ñ≥‚Å¢(ùíü)‚ààùíÆ]‚â§eœµ‚Å¢Pr‚Å¢[‚Ñ≥‚Å¢(ùíü‚Ä≤)‚ààùíÆ]+Œ¥.Prdelimited-[]‚Ñ≥ùíüùíÆsuperscripteitalic-œµPrdelimited-[]‚Ñ≥superscriptùíü‚Ä≤ùíÆùõø\mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})\in\mathcal{S}]\leq\mathrm{e}^{\epsilon}% \mathrm{Pr}[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\in\mathcal{S}]+\delta.roman_Pr [ caligraphic_M ( caligraphic_D ) ‚àà caligraphic_S ] ‚â§ roman_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Pr [ caligraphic_M ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚àà caligraphic_S ] + italic_Œ¥ .

A widely used approach to achieving differential privacy (DP) when solving ERM problem (1) is to employ differentially private stochastic gradient descent (Abadi et al., 2016) and its variants, such as DP-Adam and DP-Lora (Yu et al., 2021). To ensure DP, DPSGD leverages the Gaussian mechanism (Dwork & Roth, 2014; Abadi et al., 2016), injecting carefully calibrated Gaussian noise into the gradients at each iteration of the optimization process. This noise injection effectively masks the contribution of individual data points, thereby providing the desired privacy guarantee.

Definition 2 (Gaussian Mechanism (Dwork & Roth, 2014; Balle & Wang, 2018))

Suppose an algorithm ùíú:ùíü‚Üí‚Ñùd:ùíú‚Üíùíüsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_A : caligraphic_D ‚Üí blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2}roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sensitivity ŒîùíúsubscriptŒîùíú\Delta_{\mathcal{A}}roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., maxùíü,ùíü‚Ä≤‚Å°‚à•ùíú‚Å¢(ùíü)‚àíùíú‚Å¢(ùíü‚Ä≤)‚à•‚â§Œîùíú.subscriptùíüsuperscriptùíü‚Ä≤ùíúùíüùíúsuperscriptùíü‚Ä≤subscriptŒîùíú\max_{\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}}\left\lVert\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D})-% \mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\right\rVert\leq\Delta_{\mathcal{A}}.roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D ) - caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚à• ‚â§ roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Then, for any œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0italic_œµ > 0 and Œ¥‚â§0.05ùõø0.05\delta\leq 0.05italic_Œ¥ ‚â§ 0.05, by adding a carefully chosen random Gaussian noise to the output of the algorithm, we can make the algorithm (œµ,Œ¥)italic-œµùõø(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_œµ , italic_Œ¥ )-DP. More specifically, the mechanism M‚Å¢(x)=ùíú‚Å¢(x)+ùê∞,with‚Å¢ùê∞‚àºùí©‚Å¢(0,œÉDP2‚Å¢Id)formulae-sequenceùëÄùë•ùíúùë•ùê∞similar-towithùê∞ùí©0superscriptsubscriptùúéDP2subscriptùêºùëëM(x)=\mathcal{A}(x)+\mathbf{w},\mathrm{with}~{}\mathbf{w}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,% \sigma_{\textup{DP}}^{2}I_{d})italic_M ( italic_x ) = caligraphic_A ( italic_x ) + bold_w , roman_with bold_w ‚àº caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT DP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and œÉDPsubscriptùúéDP\sigma_{\text{DP}}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT DP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT \xweditsatisfies Œ¶‚Å¢(Œîùíú2‚Å¢œÉDP‚àíœµ‚Å¢œÉDPŒîùíú)‚àíeœµ‚Å¢Œ¶‚Å¢(‚àíŒîùíú2‚Å¢œÉDP‚àíœµ‚Å¢œÉDPŒîùíú)‚â§Œ¥Œ¶subscriptŒîùíú2subscriptùúéDPitalic-œµsubscriptùúéDPsubscriptŒîùíúsuperscripteitalic-œµŒ¶subscriptŒîùíú2subscriptùúéDPitalic-œµsubscriptùúéDPsubscriptŒîùíúùõø\Phi\left(\frac{\Delta_{\mathcal{A}}}{2\sigma_{\text{DP}}}-\frac{\epsilon% \sigma_{\text{DP}}}{\Delta_{\mathcal{A}}}\right)-\mathrm{e}^{\epsilon}\Phi% \left(-\frac{\Delta_{\mathcal{A}}}{2\sigma_{\text{DP}}}-\frac{\epsilon\sigma_{% \text{DP}}}{\Delta_{\mathcal{A}}}\right)\leq\deltaroman_Œ¶ ( divide start_ARG roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT DP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_œµ italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT DP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) - roman_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œ¶ ( - divide start_ARG roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT DP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_œµ italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT DP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ‚â§ italic_Œ¥ is (œµ,Œ¥)italic-œµùõø(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_œµ , italic_Œ¥ )-DP, where Œ¶‚Å¢(t)=‚Ñô‚Å¢[ùí©‚Å¢(0,1)‚â§t]Œ¶ùë°‚Ñôdelimited-[]ùí©01ùë°\Phi(t)=\mathbb{P}[\mathcal{N}(0,1)\leq t]roman_Œ¶ ( italic_t ) = blackboard_P [ caligraphic_N ( 0 , 1 ) ‚â§ italic_t ] is the cumulative density function of normal distribution.

The DPSGD algorithm, outlined in Algorithm 1, operates by first sampling a mini-batch ‚Ñ¨tsubscript‚Ñ¨ùë°\mathcal{B}_{t}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of size BùêµBitalic_B and computing the per-sample gradients at each iteration tùë°titalic_t. To guarantee differential privacy, it then applies the Gaussian mechanism, which involves clipping each per-sample gradient to bound its sensitivity to a maximum value Cùê∂Citalic_C and subsequently injecting Gaussian noise. The clipping operation clip‚Å¢(‚àáf,C)=min‚Å°{1,C‚à•‚àáf‚à•}‚ãÖ‚àáf,clip‚àáùëìùê∂‚ãÖ1ùê∂delimited-‚à•‚à•‚àáùëì‚àáùëì\mathrm{clip}\left(\nabla f,C\right)=\min\left\{1,\frac{C}{\left\lVert\nabla f% \right\rVert}\right\}\cdot\nabla f,roman_clip ( ‚àá italic_f , italic_C ) = roman_min { 1 , divide start_ARG italic_C end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• ‚àá italic_f ‚à• end_ARG } ‚ãÖ ‚àá italic_f , often implemented by scaling the gradient when its norm exceeds Cùê∂Citalic_C, limits the influence of any single data point, while the added noise further masks individual contributions, ensuring the desired privacy level (Abadi et al., 2016).

Theorem 1 (Privacy Guarantee (Abadi et al., 2016))

Given the number of samples NùëÅNitalic_N, the batch-size BùêµBitalic_B, total number of iterations TùëáTitalic_T and clipping threshold Cùê∂Citalic_C, there exist positive constants u,vùë¢ùë£u,vitalic_u , italic_v, such that for any œµ<u‚Å¢B2‚Å¢TN2italic-œµùë¢superscriptùêµ2ùëásuperscriptùëÅ2\epsilon<\frac{uB^{2}T}{N^{2}}italic_œµ < divide start_ARG italic_u italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG and 0<Œ¥0ùõø0<\delta0 < italic_Œ¥, by choosing œÉDP2‚â•v‚Å¢C2‚Å¢T‚Å¢ln‚Å°(1Œ¥)N2‚Å¢œµ2superscriptsubscriptùúéDP2ùë£superscriptùê∂2ùëá1ùõøsuperscriptùëÅ2superscriptitalic-œµ2\sigma_{\textup{DP}}^{2}\geq v\frac{C^{2}T\ln(\frac{1}{\delta})}{N^{2}\epsilon% ^{2}}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT DP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â• italic_v divide start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T roman_ln ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ¥ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG, Algorithm 1 is (œµ,Œ¥)italic-œµùõø(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_œµ , italic_Œ¥ )-DP.

Theorem 1 implies that the variance of the DP noise injected into the gradients, ùîº‚Å°[‚à•ùê∞t‚à•2]=d‚Å¢œÉDP2ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùê∞ùë°2ùëësubscriptsuperscriptùúé2DP\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}\right\rVert^{2}]=d\sigma^{% 2}_{\mathrm{DP}}blackboard_E [ ‚à• bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = italic_d italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_DP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, scales linearly with both the number of iterations TùëáTitalic_T and the number of parameters dùëëditalic_d. This presents a significant challenge in modern deep learning, where models size dùëëditalic_d is large (e.g., 22‚Å¢M22ùëÄ22M22 italic_M-632‚Å¢M632ùëÄ632M632 italic_M for ViT (Dosovitskiy et al., 2020), 137‚Å¢M137ùëÄ137M137 italic_M-1.6‚Å¢B1.6ùêµ1.6B1.6 italic_B for GPT-2 (Radford et al., 2019)) and require extensive training (e.g., 300‚Å¢K300ùêæ300K300 italic_K for ViT (Dosovitskiy et al., 2020) and 250‚Å¢K250ùêæ250K250 italic_K for training Llama (Touvron et al., 2023)). Consequently, the magnitude of the injected DP noise can become substantial, leading to a considerable degradation in model performance.

2.3 Kalman filter

The Kalman filter is a powerful algorithm that provides estimates of unknown variables by iteratively incorporating a series of measurements over time (Welch et al., 1995). To illustrate its application, let us consider a linear dynamic system characterized by the System update and Observation equations:

ùúΩtsubscriptùúΩùë°\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ùêÄ‚Å¢ùúΩt‚àí1+ùêÆt+ùêØt,absentùêÄsubscriptùúΩùë°1subscriptùêÆùë°subscriptùêØùë°\displaystyle=\mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t-1}+\mathbf{u}_{t}+\mathbf{v}_{t},= bold_A bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (System update) (2)
ùùçtsubscriptùùçùë°\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\psi}_{t}bold_italic_œà start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ùêÇ‚Å¢ùúΩt+ùê∞t,absentùêÇsubscriptùúΩùë°subscriptùê∞ùë°\displaystyle=\mathbf{C}\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}+\mathbf{w}_{t},= bold_C bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (Observation)

where ùêÄ‚àà‚ÑùdŒ∏√ódŒ∏ùêÄsuperscript‚ÑùsubscriptùëëùúÉsubscriptùëëùúÉ\mathbf{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\theta}\times d_{\theta}}bold_A ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT √ó italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ùêÇ‚àà‚Ñùdœà√ódŒ∏ùêÇsuperscript‚ÑùsubscriptùëëùúìsubscriptùëëùúÉ\mathbf{C}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\psi}\times d_{\theta}}bold_C ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œà end_POSTSUBSCRIPT √ó italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are the transition and observation matrices; ùúΩt‚àà‚ÑùdŒ∏subscriptùúΩùë°superscript‚ÑùsubscriptùëëùúÉ\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\theta}}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the unknown variable to be tracked/estimated; ùùçt‚àà‚Ñùdœàsubscriptùùçùë°superscript‚Ñùsubscriptùëëùúì\boldsymbol{\psi}_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\psi}}bold_italic_œà start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œà end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denotes the observation of the system; ùêÆt‚àà‚ÑùdŒ∏subscriptùêÆùë°superscript‚ÑùsubscriptùëëùúÉ\mathbf{u}_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\theta}}bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denotes the known input; and ùêØt‚àà‚ÑùdŒ∏,ùê∞t‚àà‚Ñùdœàformulae-sequencesubscriptùêØùë°superscript‚ÑùsubscriptùëëùúÉsubscriptùê∞ùë°superscript‚Ñùsubscriptùëëùúì\mathbf{v}_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\theta}},\mathbf{w}_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\psi}}bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œà end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are the process and observation noises that follow Gaussian distribution ùí©‚Å¢(0,Œ£ùêØ),ùí©‚Å¢(0,Œ£ùê∞)ùí©0subscriptŒ£ùêØùí©0subscriptŒ£ùê∞\mathcal{N}(0,\Sigma_{\mathbf{v}}),\mathcal{N}(0,\Sigma_{\mathbf{w}})caligraphic_N ( 0 , roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , caligraphic_N ( 0 , roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), respectively. Then, the Kalman filter uses the following updates to track {ùúΩt}subscriptùúΩùë°\{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}\}{ bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } (Welch et al., 1995):

ùúΩ~t|t‚àí1subscript~ùúΩconditionalùë°ùë°1\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t|t-1}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œ∏ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ùêÄ‚Å¢ùúΩ~t‚àí1+ùêÆtabsentùêÄsubscript~ùúΩùë°1subscriptùêÆùë°\displaystyle=\mathbf{A}\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t-1}+\mathbf{u}_{t}= bold_A over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œ∏ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Prediction) (3)
ùêèt|t‚àí1subscriptùêèconditionalùë°ùë°1\displaystyle\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ùêÄùêèt‚àí1‚Å¢ùêÄ‚ä§+Œ£ùêØabsentsubscriptùêÄùêèùë°1superscriptùêÄtopsubscriptŒ£ùêØ\displaystyle=\mathbf{A}\mathbf{P}_{t-1}\mathbf{A}^{\top}+\Sigma_{\mathbf{v}}= bold_AP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
ùêätsubscriptùêäùë°\displaystyle\mathbf{K}_{t}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ùêèt|t‚àí1‚Å¢ùêÇ‚ä§‚Å¢(ùêÇùêèt|t‚àí1‚Å¢ùêÇ‚ä§+Œ£ùê∞)‚àí1absentsubscriptùêèconditionalùë°ùë°1superscriptùêÇtopsuperscriptsubscriptùêÇùêèconditionalùë°ùë°1superscriptùêÇtopsubscriptŒ£ùê∞1\displaystyle=\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}\mathbf{C}^{\top}(\mathbf{C}\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}% \mathbf{C}^{\top}+\Sigma_{\mathbf{w}})^{-1}= bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_CP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
ùúΩ~tsubscript~ùúΩùë°\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œ∏ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(ùêàdŒ∏‚àíùêät‚Å¢ùêÇ)‚Å¢ùúΩ~t|t‚àí1+ùêät‚Å¢ùùçtabsentsubscriptùêàsubscriptùëëùúÉsubscriptùêäùë°ùêÇsubscript~ùúΩconditionalùë°ùë°1subscriptùêäùë°subscriptùùçùë°\displaystyle=(\mathbf{I}_{d_{\theta}}-\mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C})\tilde{% \boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t|t-1}+\mathbf{K}_{t}\boldsymbol{\psi}_{t}= ( bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C ) over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œ∏ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_œà start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Correction)
ùêètsubscriptùêèùë°\displaystyle\mathbf{P}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(ùêàdŒ∏‚àíùêät‚Å¢ùêÇ)‚Å¢ùêèt|t‚àí1.absentsubscriptùêàsubscriptùëëùúÉsubscriptùêäùë°ùêÇsubscriptùêèconditionalùë°ùë°1\displaystyle=(\mathbf{I}_{d_{\theta}}-\mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C})\mathbf{P}_{t|% t-1}.= ( bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C ) bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

The filter first predicts the state ùúΩ~t|t‚àí1subscript~ùúΩconditionalùë°ùë°1\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t|t-1}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œ∏ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by the system dynamics, and compute the filter gain ùêät‚àà‚ÑùdŒ∏√ódœàsubscriptùêäùë°superscript‚ÑùsubscriptùëëùúÉsubscriptùëëùúì\mathbf{K}_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\theta}\times d_{\psi}}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT √ó italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œà end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT based on the covariance matrix ùêèt‚àà‚ÑùdŒ∏√ódŒ∏subscriptùêèùë°superscript‚ÑùsubscriptùëëùúÉsubscriptùëëùúÉ\mathbf{P}_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\theta}\times d_{\theta}}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT √ó italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and corrects the prediction with system observation ùùçtsubscriptùùçùë°\boldsymbol{\psi}_{t}bold_italic_œà start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to obtain ùúΩ~tsubscript~ùúΩùë°\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œ∏ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The Kalman filter makes use of both the noisy observation and the prior knowledge of the system dynamics to obtain an accurate estimation of the state ùúΩtsubscriptùúΩùë°\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In this work, we treat the privatized gradients in the DP optimization as noisy observations of the true underlying gradients. By constructing gradient dynamics using Taylor expansion, we establish a framework for applying the Kalman filter to refine these noisy observations and obtain more accurate gradient estimates. To ensure practical applicability for large-scale models, we simplify the Kalman filter, significantly reducing its memory and computational footprint. These improved gradient estimates ultimately lead to enhanced performance in differentially private optimizers.

2.4 Related Works

Optimization with filters and controllers: The use of filters and controllers in designing and analyzing optimization algorithms has a rich history. Researchers have leveraged high-pass and low-pass filters to enhance gradient estimation in zeroth-order optimization (Chen et al., 2022), employed PID controllers for both centralized and distributed optimization (Wang et al., 2020b), and analyzed optimizers through the lens of control theory, treating them as dynamic systems (Lessard et al., 2016; Hu & Lessard, 2017; Muehlebach & Jordan, 2019; Mohammadi et al., 2024; Badithela & Seiler, 2019; Cyrus et al., 2018; Scherer et al., 2023; Zhang et al., 2023).

Kalman filter for optimization: The Kalman filter has been utilized in convex optimization for reducing stochastic gradient noise (Bittner & Pronzato, 2004; Vuckovic, 2018). Vuckovic (2018) uses the dynamics of the optimization variable and the gradient to construct the Kalman filter to analyze and improve the performance of momentum methods. Bittner & Pronzato (2004) uses gradient and Hessian as its states to construct the dynamic system for SGD to construct a stopping rule. However, these approaches, with their direct application of the Kalman filter, incur prohibitively high computational and memory costs, ranging from ùí™‚Å¢(d3)ùí™superscriptùëë3\mathcal{O}(d^{3})caligraphic_O ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) to ùí™‚Å¢(d6)ùí™superscriptùëë6\mathcal{O}(d^{6})caligraphic_O ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), rendering them impractical for training large-scale machine learning models.

Improving DP optimization: Numerous techniques have been proposed to enhance DP optimization by mitigating the impact of DP noise. These include adaptive gradient clipping methods that dynamically adjust clipping thresholds (Andrew et al., 2021; Bu et al., 2024), parameter-efficient training strategies employing adapters, low-rank weights, or quantization (Yu et al., 2021; Luo et al., 2021; Yu et al., 2021), and the design of specialized model architectures less susceptible to noise perturbations (De et al., 2022; Papernot et al., 2021; Wang et al., 2020a). Furthermore, drawing inspiration from signal processing, researchers have explored the use of colored high-frequency DP noise to separate it from the gradient (Koloskova et al., 2023) and the application of low-pass filters to extract the gradient signal from noisy observations (Zhang et al., 2024a).

3 Algorithm design

This section introduces the general Noise Reduction for Differentially Private Optimizers with Simplified Kalman Filter (DiSK) framework. This approach leverages the inherent dynamics of the gradient and employs Kalman filtering to obtain denoised estimates of the true gradients from their noisy, privatized counterparts. To enhance its practicality for modern deep learning, Section 3.2 details a simplified version of the Kalman filter updates, designed for memory and computational efficiency.

3.1 Gradient dynamic and Kalman filter

To explain our idea of using the Kalman filter for denoising, let us start by first establishing a dynamic system for the gradients, comprising a ‚Äúsystem update‚Äù equation and an ‚Äúobservation‚Äù equation: The system update of the gradient dynamics can be derived by the Taylor expansion and quantifying the change of the gradient at iteration tùë°titalic_t:

‚àáF‚Å¢(ùê±t)‚àáùêπsubscriptùê±ùë°\displaystyle\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t})‚àá italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =‚àáF‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1)+‚àá2F‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1)‚ä§‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àíùê±t‚àí1)+R‚Å¢(ùê±t)absent‚àáùêπsubscriptùê±ùë°1superscript‚àá2ùêπsuperscriptsubscriptùê±ùë°1topsubscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1ùëÖsubscriptùê±ùë°\displaystyle=\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t-1})+\nabla^{2}F(\mathbf{x}_{t-1})^{\top}(% \mathbf{x}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{t-1})+R(\mathbf{x}_{t})= ‚àá italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ‚àá start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_R ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (4)
=‚àáF‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1)+ùêát‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àíùê±t‚àí1)+ùêØt,absent‚àáùêπsubscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùêáùë°subscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùêØùë°\displaystyle=\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t-1})+\mathbf{H}_{t}(\mathbf{x}_{t}-\mathbf% {x}_{t-1})+\mathbf{v}_{t},= ‚àá italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

where ùêát:=‚àá2F‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1)‚àà‚Ñùd√ódassignsubscriptùêáùë°superscript‚àá2ùêπsubscriptùê±ùë°1superscript‚Ñùùëëùëë\mathbf{H}_{t}:=\nabla^{2}F(\mathbf{x}_{t-1})\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := ‚àá start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d √ó italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ùêØt=12‚Å¢‚à´01‚àá3F‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1)‚Å¢(z‚Å¢ùê±t+(1‚àíz)‚Å¢ùê±t‚àí1)‚äó2‚Å¢dzsubscriptùêØùë°12superscriptsubscript01superscript‚àá3ùêπsubscriptùê±ùë°1superscriptùëßsubscriptùê±ùë°1ùëßsubscriptùê±ùë°1tensor-productabsent2differential-dùëß\mathbf{v}_{t}=\frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{1}\nabla^{3}F(\mathbf{x}_{t-1})(z\mathbf{x% }_{t}+(1-z)\mathbf{x}_{t-1})^{\otimes 2}\mathrm{d}zbold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àá start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_z bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_z ) bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚äó 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_z is the remainder and (‚ãÖ)‚äósuperscript‚ãÖtensor-product(\cdot)^{\otimes}( ‚ãÖ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚äó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denotes the tensor vector product. The observation of the system is defined as the privatized gradient ùê†tsubscriptùê†ùë°\mathbf{g}_{t}bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is a stochastic mapping of the true gradient:

ùê†t=1B‚Å¢‚àëŒæ‚àà‚Ñ¨tclip‚Å¢(‚àáf‚Å¢(ùê±t,Œæ),C)+ùê∞t=ùêÇt‚Å¢‚àáF‚Å¢(ùê±t)+ùê∞t‚Ä≤,subscriptùê†ùë°1ùêµsubscriptùúâsubscript‚Ñ¨ùë°clip‚àáùëìsubscriptùê±ùë°ùúâùê∂subscriptùê∞ùë°subscriptùêÇùë°‚àáùêπsubscriptùê±ùë°subscriptsuperscriptùê∞‚Ä≤ùë°\mathbf{g}_{t}=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{\xi\in\mathcal{B}_{t}}\mathrm{clip}\left(% \nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t},\xi),C\right)+\mathbf{w}_{t}=\mathbf{C}_{t}\nabla F(% \mathbf{x}_{t})+\mathbf{w}^{\prime}_{t},bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ ‚àà caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clip ( ‚àá italic_f ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œæ ) , italic_C ) + bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àá italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (5)

where ùê∞t‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùê∞‚Ä≤ùë°\mathbf{w}^{\prime}_{t}bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the observation noise containing the DP noise and sub-sampling noise. ùêÇtsubscriptùêÇùë°\mathbf{C}_{t}bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the observation matrix. If the clipping operation is inactive and ‚Ñ¨=ùíü‚Ñ¨ùíü\mathcal{B}=\mathcal{D}caligraphic_B = caligraphic_D, i.e., the full batch gradient is used, then ùêÇt=ùêàdsubscriptùêÇùë°subscriptùêàùëë\mathbf{C}_{t}=\mathbf{I}_{d}bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Otherwise, ùêÇtsubscriptùêÇùë°\mathbf{C}_{t}bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT depends on the clipping factor and the mini-batch ‚Ñ¨‚Ñ¨\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B. Combining the system update (4) and the observation (5), we can model the system dynamic of the gradient as:

‚àáF‚Å¢(ùê±t)‚àáùêπsubscriptùê±ùë°\displaystyle\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t})‚àá italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =‚àáF‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àí1)+ùêát‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àíùê±t‚àí1)+ùêØt,absent‚àáùêπsubscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùêáùë°subscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1subscriptùêØùë°\displaystyle=\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t-1})+\mathbf{H}_{t}(\mathbf{x}_{t}-\mathbf% {x}_{t-1})+\mathbf{v}_{t},\qquad= ‚àá italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (System update) (6)
ùê†tsubscriptùê†ùë°\displaystyle\mathbf{g}_{t}bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ùêÇt‚Å¢‚àáF‚Å¢(ùê±t)+ùê∞t‚Ä≤.absentsubscriptùêÇùë°‚àáùêπsubscriptùê±ùë°subscriptsuperscriptùê∞‚Ä≤ùë°\displaystyle=\mathbf{C}_{t}\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t})+\mathbf{w}^{\prime}_{t}.\qquad= bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àá italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (Observation)

Let us compare our dynamic system with the general one in (2): In our dynamic system, the gradient ‚àáF‚Å¢(ùê±t)‚àáùêπsubscriptùê±ùë°\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t})‚àá italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) plays the role of the state ùúΩt,subscriptùúΩùë°\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t},bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,. Other parameters in (2) must change to the followings to obtain our gradient dynamic: ùêÄ=ùêàd,ùêÇ=ùêÇtformulae-sequenceùêÄsubscriptùêàùëëùêÇsubscriptùêÇùë°\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{I}_{d},\mathbf{C}=\mathbf{C}_{t}bold_A = bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_C = bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the input ùêÆt=ùêát‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àíùê±t‚àí1)subscriptùêÆùë°subscriptùêáùë°subscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1\mathbf{u}_{t}=\mathbf{H}_{t}(\mathbf{x}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{t-1})bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and the observation ùùçt=ùê†tsubscriptùùçùë°subscriptùê†ùë°\boldsymbol{\psi}_{t}=\mathbf{g}_{t}bold_italic_œà start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. With the above mapping, we can apply the Kalman filter that combines the system update and the observation of the gradient to improve the overall estimation quality of the actual gradient beyond only using the observation ùê†tsubscriptùê†ùë°\mathbf{g}_{t}bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, there are two key challenges when applying Kalman filter to (6): 1) the input ùêát‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àíùê±t‚àí1)subscriptùêáùë°subscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1\mathbf{H}_{t}(\mathbf{x}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{t-1})bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is hard to obtain as computing the Hessian matrix ùêátsubscriptùêáùë°\mathbf{H}_{t}bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is challenging for large models, and we can only approximate ùêát‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àíùê±t‚àí1)subscriptùêáùë°subscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1\mathbf{H}_{t}(\mathbf{x}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{t-1})bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ); 2) the observation matrix ùêÇtsubscriptùêÇùë°\mathbf{C}_{t}bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an unknown time-varying random matrix. Due to these differences, the traditional Kalman filter (Welch et al., 1995) cannot be directly applied. Instead, we apply the Kalman filter with noisy input and multiplicative observation noise proposed in Wu et al. (2016) to our system (6), leading to the update rules:

ùê†~t|t‚àí1subscript~ùê†conditionalùë°ùë°1\displaystyle\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t|t-1}over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ùê†~t‚àí1+ùêá~t‚Å¢(ùê±t‚àíùê±t‚àí1)absentsubscript~ùê†ùë°1subscript~ùêáùë°subscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±ùë°1\displaystyle=\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t-1}+{\color[rgb]{1,0,1}\tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{% t}}(\mathbf{x}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{t-1})= over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG bold_H end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (Prediction)
ùêèt|t‚àí1subscriptùêèconditionalùë°ùë°1\displaystyle\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ùêèt‚àí1+Œ£ùêá+Œ£ùêØabsentsubscriptùêèùë°1subscriptŒ£ùêásubscriptŒ£ùêØ\displaystyle=\mathbf{P}_{t-1}+{\color[rgb]{1,0,1}\Sigma_{\mathbf{H}}}+\Sigma_% {\mathbf{v}}= bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
ùêätsubscriptùêäùë°\displaystyle\mathbf{K}_{t}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ùêèt|t‚àí1ùîº[ùêÇt]‚ä§(Œ£ùê∞+ùîº[ùêÇt](Œ£ùêÇùêít+ùêèt|t‚àí1)ùîº[ùêÇt]‚ä§‚àíŒ£ùêá)‚àí1\displaystyle=\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}{\color[rgb]{1,0,1}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[% \mathbf{C}_{t}]^{\top}}\left(\Sigma_{\mathbf{w}}+{\color[rgb]{1,0,1}% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\mathbf{C}_{t}]}\left({\color[rgb]{1,0,1}\Sigma_{% \mathbf{C}}\mathbf{S}_{t}}+\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}\right){\color[rgb]{1,0,1}% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\mathbf{C}_{t}]^{\top}-\Sigma_{\mathbf{H}}}\right)^{% -1}= bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E [ bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + blackboard_E [ bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ( roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) blackboard_E [ bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
ùê†~tsubscript~ùê†ùë°\displaystyle\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ùê†~t|t‚àí1+ùêät‚Å¢(ùê†t‚àíùîº‚Å°[ùêÇt]‚Å¢ùê†~t|t‚àí1)absentsubscript~ùê†conditionalùë°ùë°1subscriptùêäùë°subscriptùê†ùë°ùîºsubscriptùêÇùë°subscript~ùê†conditionalùë°ùë°1\displaystyle=\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t|t-1}+\mathbf{K}_{t}(\mathbf{g}_{t}-{\color% [rgb]{1,0,1}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\mathbf{C}_{t}]}\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t|t-% 1})= over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - blackboard_E [ bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (Correction)
ùêètsubscriptùêèùë°\displaystyle\mathbf{P}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(ùêà‚àíùêät‚Å¢ùîº‚Å°[ùêÇt])‚Å¢ùêèt|t‚àí1absentùêàsubscriptùêäùë°ùîºsubscriptùêÇùë°subscriptùêèconditionalùë°ùë°1\displaystyle=(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{K}_{t}{\color[rgb]{1,0,1}\operatorname{% \mathbb{E}}[\mathbf{C}_{t}]})\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}= ( bold_I - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E [ bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
ùêítsubscriptùêíùë°\displaystyle{\color[rgb]{1,0,1}\mathbf{S}_{t}}bold_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ùîº‚Å°[ùê†~t‚Å¢ùê†~t‚ä§],absentùîºsubscript~ùê†ùë°superscriptsubscript~ùê†ùë°top\displaystyle{\color[rgb]{1,0,1}=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_% {t}\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top}]},= blackboard_E [ over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ,

where ùêètsubscriptùêèùë°\mathbf{P}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the covariance matrix of ùê†~t,subscript~ùê†ùë°\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t},over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , Œ£ùêá,Œ£ùê∞,Œ£ùêÇ,Œ£ùêØsubscriptŒ£ùêásubscriptŒ£ùê∞subscriptŒ£ùêÇsubscriptŒ£ùêØ\Sigma_{\mathbf{H}},\Sigma_{\mathbf{w}},\Sigma_{\mathbf{C}},\Sigma_{\mathbf{v}}roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the covariance matrices of the random variables ùêát,ùê∞t,ùêÇt,ùêØtsubscriptùêáùë°subscriptùê∞ùë°subscriptùêÇùë°subscriptùêØùë°\mathbf{H}_{t},\mathbf{w}_{t},\mathbf{C}_{t},\mathbf{v}_{t}bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively, and ùêá~tsubscript~ùêáùë°\tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_H end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an instantiation/observation of the unknown Hessian matrix ùêátsubscriptùêáùë°\mathbf{H}_{t}bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The difference between the above Kalman filter and the original Kalman filter (3) is highlighted in magenta color. The variance of the Hessian ùêá~tsubscript~ùêáùë°\tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_H end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT plays a role in updating ùêèt|t‚àí1,ùêätsubscriptùêèconditionalùë°ùë°1subscriptùêäùë°\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1},\mathbf{K}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the expectation ùîº‚Å°[ùêÇt]ùîºsubscriptùêÇùë°\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\mathbf{C}_{t}]blackboard_E [ bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] of the random observation matrix ùêÇtsubscriptùêÇùë°\mathbf{C}_{t}bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is used for the updates and its variance Œ£ùêÇsubscriptŒ£ùêÇ\Sigma_{\mathbf{C}}roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT also appears in the update of ùêätsubscriptùêäùë°\mathbf{K}_{t}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Compared to the noisy gradient ùê†tsubscriptùê†ùë°\mathbf{g}_{t}bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the output of the Kalman filter ùê†~tsubscript~ùê†ùë°\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has a smaller variance, resulting in improved performance when used in DP optimizers.

The resulting optimizer with the Kalman filter is given in Algorithm 2. The hyper-parameters of the Kalman filter are the expected observation matrix ùîº‚Å°[ùêÇ]ùîºùêÇ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\mathbf{C}]blackboard_E [ bold_C ] and the variances of the noises in the system, i.e., œÉùê∞2,Œ£ùêÇ,Œ£ùêásubscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùê∞subscriptŒ£ùêÇsubscriptŒ£ùêá\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{w}},\Sigma_{\mathbf{C}},\Sigma_{\mathbf{H}}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Here, we dropped subscript tùë°titalic_t for ùêÇtsubscriptùêÇùë°\mathbf{C}_{t}bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for simplicity in our modeling.

3.2 Algorithm simplification

While Algorithm 2 provides a general framework for applying Kalman filtering to various optimizers, it faces significant challenges in terms of computational and memory demands. Specifically, accurately computing the Hessian matrix (ùêáùêá\mathbf{H}bold_H) for large models under DP constraints is infeasible, the matrix inversion step introduces a cubic computational complexity (ùí™‚Å¢(d3)ùí™superscriptùëë3\mathcal{O}(d^{3})caligraphic_O ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )), and storing the covariance matrix (ùêètsubscriptùêèùë°\mathbf{P}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) at each iteration requires quadratic memory (ùí™‚Å¢(d2)ùí™superscriptùëë2\mathcal{O}(d^{2})caligraphic_O ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )). To address these limitations and arrive at a practical and memory-efficient algorithm, we propose the following simplifications:

Constant ùêÇtsubscriptùêÇùë°\mathbf{C}_{t}bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: We simplify the random matrix ùêÇtsubscriptùêÇùë°\mathbf{C}_{t}bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to an identity matrix ùêàdsubscriptùêàùëë\mathbf{I}_{d}bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and simply model the randomness in the observation as additive noise only. This simplification is achieved in two steps corresponding to the two sources of randomness in ùêÇtsubscriptùêÇùë°\mathbf{C}_{t}bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. First, we remove the impact of clipping in ùêÇtsubscriptùêÇùë°\mathbf{C}_{t}bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is justified when 1) the clipping threshold Cùê∂Citalic_C is large enough so that clipping is inactive; or when 2) the clipped gradient ‚àáFC‚Å¢(ùê±)‚àásubscriptùêπùê∂ùê±\nabla F_{C}(\mathbf{x})‚àá italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) has zero curl, so that our method optimizes FC‚Å¢(ùê±)subscriptùêπùê∂ùê±F_{C}(\mathbf{x})italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ), where

FC‚Å¢(ùê±)=‚à´01‚àáFC‚Å¢(z‚Å¢ùê±)‚ä§‚Å¢ùê±‚Å¢dz,‚àáFC‚Å¢(ùê±)=1N‚Å¢‚àëŒæ‚ààùíüclip‚Å¢(‚àáf‚Å¢(ùê±;Œæ),C).formulae-sequencesubscriptùêπùê∂ùê±subscriptsuperscript10‚àásubscriptùêπùê∂superscriptùëßùê±topùê±differential-dùëß‚àásubscriptùêπùê∂ùê±1ùëÅsubscriptùúâùíüclip‚àáùëìùê±ùúâùê∂F_{C}(\mathbf{x})=\int^{1}_{0}\nabla F_{C}(z\mathbf{x})^{\top}\mathbf{x}% \mathrm{d}z,\;\nabla F_{C}(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{\xi\in\mathcal{D}}% \mathrm{clip}\left(\nabla f(\mathbf{x};\xi),C\right).italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) = ‚à´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àá italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_z bold_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_x roman_d italic_z , ‚àá italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ ‚àà caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clip ( ‚àá italic_f ( bold_x ; italic_Œæ ) , italic_C ) . (7)

Under this assumption, the minibatch clipped gradient 1B‚Å¢‚àëŒæ‚àà‚Ñ¨clip‚Å¢(‚àáf‚Å¢(ùê±,Œæ),C)1ùêµsubscriptùúâ‚Ñ¨clip‚àáùëìùê±ùúâùê∂\frac{1}{B}\sum_{\xi\in\mathcal{B}}\mathrm{clip}\left(\nabla f(\mathbf{x},\xi)% ,C\right)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ ‚àà caligraphic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clip ( ‚àá italic_f ( bold_x , italic_Œæ ) , italic_C ) is an unbiased estimation of ‚àáFC‚Å¢(ùê±).‚àásubscriptùêπùê∂ùê±\nabla F_{C}(\mathbf{x}).‚àá italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) . Thus, ùîº‚Å°[ùêÇt]=ùêàdùîºsubscriptùêÇùë°subscriptùêàùëë\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\mathbf{C}_{t}]=\mathbf{I}_{d}blackboard_E [ bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Second, the randomness of sub-sampling in ùêÇtsubscriptùêÇùë°\mathbf{C}_{t}bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is removed by assuming that the sub-sampled mini-batch gradient only causes additive noise, i.e., 1B‚Å¢‚àëŒæ‚àà‚Ñ¨clip‚Å¢(‚àáf‚Å¢(ùê±,Œæ),C)=‚àáFC‚Å¢(ùê±)+ùê∞SGD,1ùêµsubscriptùúâ‚Ñ¨clip‚àáùëìùê±ùúâùê∂‚àásubscriptùêπùê∂ùê±subscriptùê∞SGD\frac{1}{B}\sum_{\xi\in\mathcal{B}}\mathrm{clip}\left(\nabla f(\mathbf{x},\xi)% ,C\right)=\nabla F_{C}(\mathbf{x})+\mathbf{w}_{\mathrm{SGD}},divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ ‚àà caligraphic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clip ( ‚àá italic_f ( bold_x , italic_Œæ ) , italic_C ) = ‚àá italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) + bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_SGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , so that ùêÇ=ùêàdùêÇsubscriptùêàùëë\mathbf{C}=\mathbf{I}_{d}bold_C = bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Œ£ùêÇ=0.subscriptŒ£ùêÇ0\Sigma_{\mathbf{C}}=0.roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 .

Hessian estimation: We apply the following ‚Äútrick‚Äù to bypass the explicit computation of the Hessian matrix, ùêátsubscriptùêáùë°\mathbf{H}_{t}bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Instead, we approximate the Hessian-vector product, ùêát‚Å¢(ùêùt‚àí1)subscriptùêáùë°subscriptùêùùë°1\mathbf{H}_{t}(\mathbf{d}_{t-1})bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), using a finite difference method (Pearlmutter, 1994):

ùêát‚Å¢ùêùt‚àí1=‚àáF‚Å¢(ùê±t+Œ≥‚Å¢ùêùt‚àí1)‚àí‚àáF‚Å¢(ùê±t)Œ≥+ùí™‚Å¢(Œ≥)‚âà1B‚Å¢‚àëŒæ‚àà‚Ñ¨‚àáf‚Å¢(ùê±t+Œ≥‚Å¢ùêùt‚àí1;Œæ)‚àí‚àáf‚Å¢(ùê±t;Œæ)Œ≥,subscriptùêáùë°subscriptùêùùë°1‚àáùêπsubscriptùê±ùë°ùõæsubscriptùêùùë°1‚àáùêπsubscriptùê±ùë°ùõæùí™ùõæ1ùêµsubscriptùúâ‚Ñ¨‚àáùëìsubscriptùê±ùë°ùõæsubscriptùêùùë°1ùúâ‚àáùëìsubscriptùê±ùë°ùúâùõæ\mathbf{H}_{t}\mathbf{d}_{t-1}=\frac{\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t}+\gamma\mathbf{d}_% {t-1})-\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t})}{\gamma}+\mathcal{O}(\gamma)\approx\frac{1}{B}% \sum_{\xi\in\mathcal{B}}\frac{\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t}+\gamma\mathbf{d}_{t-1};% \xi)-\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t};\xi)}{\gamma},bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG ‚àá italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - ‚àá italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG + caligraphic_O ( italic_Œ≥ ) ‚âà divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ ‚àà caligraphic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG ‚àá italic_f ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Œæ ) - ‚àá italic_f ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Œæ ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG ,

This estimation eliminates the need for expensive Hessian computations and significantly reduces both memory and computational complexity.

Simplification of Œ£HsubscriptŒ£ùêª\Sigma_{H}roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: Few matrix computation steps in Algorithm 2 are extremely time-consuming and memory inefficient. Specifically, the matrix inversion in Line 8 of Algorithm 2 incurs a cubic computational cost (ùí™‚Å¢(d3)ùí™superscriptùëë3\mathcal{O}(d^{3})caligraphic_O ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )), which becomes prohibitive for large models with billions of parameters. Therefore, we simplify the algorithm by assuming that the covariance matrix in the Kalman filter is a time-invariant diagonal matrix, i.e., Œ£H=œÉH2‚Å¢ùêàdsubscriptŒ£ùêªsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùêª2subscriptùêàùëë\Sigma_{H}=\sigma_{H}^{2}\mathbf{I}_{d}roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Under this assumption, the matrices ùêètsubscriptùêèùë°\mathbf{P}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùêätsubscriptùêäùë°\mathbf{K}_{t}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT become pt‚Å¢ùêàd,kt‚Å¢ùêàdsubscriptùëùùë°subscriptùêàùëësubscriptùëòùë°subscriptùêàùëëp_{t}\mathbf{I}_{d},k_{t}\mathbf{I}_{d}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for some scalars pt,ktsubscriptùëùùë°subscriptùëòùë°p_{t},k_{t}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus, we reduce all matrix computations to efficient scalar-vector multiplications. Furthermore, the memory complexity for storing these matrices is reduced to ùí™‚Å¢(1)ùí™1\mathcal{O}(1)caligraphic_O ( 1 ), making our algorithm a viable option for DP training of large-scale models.

Filter gain simplification: With the above simplification, the updates of pt,ktsubscriptùëùùë°subscriptùëòùë°p_{t},k_{t}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT simplifies to pt=(œÉùê∞2‚àíœÉH2)‚Å¢(pt‚àí1+œÉùêØ2+œÉH2)pt‚àí1+œÉùêØ2+œÉùê∞2subscriptùëùùë°subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùê∞subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêªsubscriptùëùùë°1subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêØsubscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêªsubscriptùëùùë°1subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêØsubscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùê∞p_{t}=\frac{(\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{w}}-\sigma^{2}_{H})(p_{t-1}+\sigma^{2}_{% \mathbf{v}}+\sigma^{2}_{H})}{p_{t-1}+\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{v}}+\sigma^{2}_{% \mathbf{w}}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG ( italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, kt=pt‚àí1+œÉùêØ2+œÉH2pt‚àí1+œÉùêØ2+œÉùê∞2.subscriptùëòùë°subscriptùëùùë°1subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêØsubscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêªsubscriptùëùùë°1subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêØsubscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùê∞k_{t}=\frac{p_{t-1}+\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{v}}+\sigma^{2}_{H}}{p_{t-1}+\sigma^{2}% _{\mathbf{v}}+\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{w}}}.italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . Therefore, ktsubscriptùëòùë°k_{t}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT converges to its stable value with a linear rate, i.e., ‚à•kt‚àík‚àû‚à•=ùí™‚Å¢(ckt),delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùëòùë°subscriptùëòùí™superscriptsubscriptùëêùëòùë°\left\lVert k_{t}-k_{\infty}\right\rVert=\mathcal{O}(c_{k}^{t}),‚à• italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• = caligraphic_O ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , where ck=2‚Å¢œÉùê∞2+3‚Å¢œÉH2+œÉùêØ2‚àí(œÉùêØ2+œÉH2)‚Å¢(4‚Å¢œÉùê∞2+œÉùêØ2‚àí3‚Å¢œÉH2)2‚Å¢œÉùê∞2+3‚Å¢œÉH2+œÉùêØ2+(œÉùêØ2+œÉH2)‚Å¢(4‚Å¢œÉùê∞2+œÉùêØ2‚àí3‚Å¢œÉH2)‚àà(0,1)subscriptùëêùëò2subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùê∞3subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêªsubscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêØsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùêØ2subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêª4subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùê∞subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêØ3subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêª2subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùê∞3subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêªsubscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêØsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùêØ2subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêª4subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùê∞subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêØ3subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùêª01c_{k}=\frac{2\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{w}}+3\sigma^{2}_{H}+\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{v}}-% \sqrt{(\sigma_{\mathbf{v}}^{2}+\sigma^{2}_{H})(4\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{w}}+\sigma% ^{2}_{\mathbf{v}}-3\sigma^{2}_{H})}}{2\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{w}}+3\sigma^{2}_{H}+% \sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{v}}+\sqrt{(\sigma_{\mathbf{v}}^{2}+\sigma^{2}_{H})(4\sigma% ^{2}_{\mathbf{w}}+\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{v}}-3\sigma^{2}_{H})}}\in(0,1)italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 2 italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 3 italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - square-root start_ARG ( italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( 4 italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 3 italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 3 italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + square-root start_ARG ( italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( 4 italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 3 italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG end_ARG ‚àà ( 0 , 1 ) (see derivations in Appendix A.3). So we can use constant kt=Œ∫,‚àÄtsubscriptùëòùë°ùúÖfor-allùë°k_{t}=\kappa,\forall\;titalic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Œ∫ , ‚àÄ italic_t to further simplify the algorithm and avoid iteratively updating ptsubscriptùëùùë°p_{t}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and recomputing ktsubscriptùëòùë°k_{t}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each step.

With the above simplifications, the complex Algorithm 2 simplifies to DiSK in Algorithm 3. For a detailed walkthrough of this simplification process, please refer to Appendix A.3. This simplified algorithm computes and privatizes the linear combination of the gradient evaluated at two points, ùê±t,ùê±t+Œ≥‚Å¢ùêùtsubscriptùê±ùë°subscriptùê±ùë°ùõæsubscriptùêùùë°\mathbf{x}_{t},\mathbf{x}_{t}+\gamma\mathbf{d}_{t}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, this privatized combination undergoes exponential weighted averaging to obtain ùê†~tsubscript~ùê†ùë°\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which serves as the input to the base optimizer (Line 7 of Algorithm 3).

3.3 Additional discussion

Memory and computation cost: Algorithm 3 requires one additional forward step to compute f‚Å¢(ùê±t+Œ≥‚Å¢ùêùt‚àí1;Œæ)ùëìsubscriptùê±ùë°ùõæsubscriptùêùùë°1ùúâf(\mathbf{x}_{t}+\gamma\mathbf{d}_{t-1};\xi)italic_f ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ≥ bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Œæ ). This means that the algorithm has at most twice the computational cost of the baseline DP-SGD algorithm. Moreover, Algorithm 3 only requires two additional states to store: ùê†~tsubscript~ùê†ùë°\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùêùtsubscriptùêùùë°\mathbf{d}_{t}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Compared to DPSGD, which requires storing the model and the gradient, DiSK has at most twice the memory cost; and compared to DPAdam, which requires storing the first- and second-order moments, the algorithm has at most 1.5√ó1.5\times1.5 √ó the memory cost.

Connection to NAG and \xweditSTORM: Remarkably, Algorithm 3 has an implicit connection to the (unified) Nesterov accelerated gradient (NAG) method (Shen et al., 2023; Sutskever et al., 2013) \xweditand the Stochastic Recursive Momentum (STORM) algorithm (Cutkosky & Orabona, 2019). Specifically, by letting the OptimizerUpdate be SGD, assuming clipping is inactive, and setting ùê∞t=0subscriptùê∞ùë°0\mathbf{w}_{t}=0bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 (i.e., without privatizing the gradient) in Algorithm 3, we can make a clear connection: On one hand, DiSK reduces to NAG by choosing Œ≥=1‚àíŒ∫Œ∫,Œ∑=Œ∫,1‚àíŒ∫=Œºformulae-sequenceùõæ1ùúÖùúÖformulae-sequenceùúÇùúÖ1ùúÖùúá\gamma=\frac{1-\kappa}{\kappa},\eta=\kappa,1-\kappa=\muitalic_Œ≥ = divide start_ARG 1 - italic_Œ∫ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ∫ end_ARG , italic_Œ∑ = italic_Œ∫ , 1 - italic_Œ∫ = italic_Œº, and B=NùêµùëÅB=Nitalic_B = italic_N. On the other hand, the update of DiSK matches STORM by choosing Œ≥=‚àí1,Œ∫=Œ±formulae-sequenceùõæ1ùúÖùõº\gamma=-1,\kappa=\alphaitalic_Œ≥ = - 1 , italic_Œ∫ = italic_Œ±, and B=1ùêµ1B=1italic_B = 1. A detailed derivation and discussion is provided in Appendix A.4. This observation reveals an intriguing connection between NAG (designed for acceleration) and STORM (focused on variance reduction), unifying them within the framework of DiSK, a Kalman filtering-based algorithm.

Connection to DOPPLER: DOPPLER (Zhang et al., 2024a) and DiSK both use a filter to separate the gradient signal from the DP noise. If ùê†tsubscriptùê†ùë°\mathbf{g}_{t}bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT only evaluates the gradient at one point instead of using the linear combination of gradients at two points in Algorithm 3, Line 5, DiSK becomes DOPPLER with a first-order filter. The key difference is that DOPPLER assumes an underlying low-frequency dynamic of the gradient and applies a time-invariant low-pass filter. Designing the optimal low-pass filter relies on the prior knowledge of the gradient frequency spectrum, which is hard to obtain in practice, and implementing such a high-order low-pass filter results in a large memory overhead. While in DiSK, we do not assume the frequency property of the gradient signal. Instead, we incorporate the gradient dynamics into the filtering procedure and use the Kalman filter, a predictive filtering approach, to reduce the impact of DP noise.

4 Theoretical analysis

This section includes theoretical analyses of Algorithm 3. Our study establishes the convergence, provable noise reduction, and the privacy-utility trade-off of the algorithm. To facilitate our analysis, we make the following assumptions:

A 1 (Smoothness)

f‚Å¢(‚ãÖ,Œæ)ùëì‚ãÖùúâf(\cdot,\xi)italic_f ( ‚ãÖ , italic_Œæ ) is LùêøLitalic_L-smooth for any Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ, i.e., ‚à•‚àáf‚Å¢(ùê±;Œæ)‚àí‚àáf‚Å¢(ùê≤;Œæ)‚à•‚â§L‚Å¢‚à•ùê±‚àíùê≤‚à•,‚àÄŒæ‚ààùíü,‚àÄùê±,ùê≤‚àà‚Ñùd.formulae-sequencedelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àáùëìùê±ùúâ‚àáùëìùê≤ùúâùêødelimited-‚à•‚à•ùê±ùê≤formulae-sequencefor-allùúâùíüfor-allùê±ùê≤superscript‚Ñùùëë\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x};\xi)-\nabla f(\mathbf{y};\xi)\right\rVert\leq L% \left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVert,\;\forall\xi\in\mathcal{D},\;% \forall\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.‚à• ‚àá italic_f ( bold_x ; italic_Œæ ) - ‚àá italic_f ( bold_y ; italic_Œæ ) ‚à• ‚â§ italic_L ‚à• bold_x - bold_y ‚à• , ‚àÄ italic_Œæ ‚àà caligraphic_D , ‚àÄ bold_x , bold_y ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

A 2 (Bounded Variance)

The per-sample gradient has bounded variance with ùîºŒæ‚ààùíü‚à•‚àáf(ùê±;Œæ)‚àí‚àáF(ùê±)‚à•2‚â§œÉSGD2,‚àÄùê±‚àà‚Ñùd,\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{\xi\in\mathcal{D}}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x};% \xi)-\nabla F(\mathbf{x})\right\rVert^{2}\leq\sigma^{2}_{\text{SGD}},\;\forall% \mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ ‚àà caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• ‚àá italic_f ( bold_x ; italic_Œæ ) - ‚àá italic_F ( bold_x ) ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT SGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚àÄ bold_x ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , where ùîºŒæ‚ààùíü‚Å°[‚ãÖ]subscriptùîºùúâùíü‚ãÖ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{\xi\in\mathcal{D}}[\cdot]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ ‚àà caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ‚ãÖ ] denotes the expectation taken on the randomness over Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ that is uniformly sampled from dataset ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D.

A 3 (Bounded Gradient)

Each per-sample gradient has a bounded norm, i.e., ‚à•‚àáf‚Å¢(ùê±;Œæ)‚à•‚â§G,‚àÄùê±‚àà‚Ñùd,‚àÄŒæ‚ààùíü.formulae-sequencedelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àáùëìùê±ùúâùê∫formulae-sequencefor-allùê±superscript‚Ñùùëëfor-allùúâùíü\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x};\xi)\right\rVert\leq G,\;\forall\mathbf{x}\in% \mathbb{R}^{d},\forall\xi\in\mathcal{D}.‚à• ‚àá italic_f ( bold_x ; italic_Œæ ) ‚à• ‚â§ italic_G , ‚àÄ bold_x ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ‚àÄ italic_Œæ ‚àà caligraphic_D .

Let us briefly comment on these assumptions: A1 and A2 are standard in non-convex optimization (Allen-Zhu & Hazan, 2016; Zaheer et al., 2018; Abadi et al., 2016); and A3 is commonly used in analyzing the convergence of DP algorithms (Abadi et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2020a; Andrew et al., 2021) to avoid introducing the clipping bias. Since the impact of clipping is not the major focus of this paper, we follow this tradition and use A3 to simplify our theoretical analysis.

4.1 Convergence analysis

We provide the following convergence results for Algorithm 3, assuming œÉDPsubscriptùúéDP\sigma_{\mathrm{DP}}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_DP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT being a constant.

Theorem 2

Assume A1-A3 hold. Fix œÉDP2superscriptsubscriptùúéDP2\sigma_{\mathrm{DP}}^{2}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_DP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and choose C‚â•(1+2‚Å¢(1‚àíŒ∫)Œ∫)‚Å¢Gùê∂121ùúÖùúÖùê∫C\geq(1+\frac{2(1-\kappa)}{\kappa})Gitalic_C ‚â• ( 1 + divide start_ARG 2 ( 1 - italic_Œ∫ ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ∫ end_ARG ) italic_G, Œ∫,Œ∑ùúÖùúÇ\kappa,\etaitalic_Œ∫ , italic_Œ∑ satisfy

Œ∑<1+Œ∫2‚Å¢L‚Å¢(1+2‚Å¢(1‚àíŒ∫)2‚Å¢Œ≤‚Å¢L‚Å¢(2+|1+Œ≥|‚Å¢CŒ≥)),Œ∫>1‚àí11+4‚Å¢Œ∑2‚Å¢L2+\xwedit‚Å¢|1+Œ≥|‚Å¢(Œ∫+2‚Å¢Œ∑2‚Å¢L2‚Å¢CŒ≥),formulae-sequenceùúÇ1ùúÖ2ùêø12superscript1ùúÖ2ùõΩùêø21ùõæsubscriptùê∂ùõæùúÖ1114superscriptùúÇ2superscriptùêø2\xwedit1ùõæùúÖ2superscriptùúÇ2superscriptùêø2subscriptùê∂ùõæ\eta<\frac{1+\kappa}{2L(1+2(1-\kappa)^{2}\beta L(2+\left\lvert 1+\gamma\right% \rvert C_{\gamma}))},\;\kappa>1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+4\eta^{2}L^{2}+\xwedit{\left% \lvert 1+\gamma\right\rvert\left(\kappa+2\eta^{2}L^{2}C_{\gamma}\right)}}},italic_Œ∑ < divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Œ∫ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L ( 1 + 2 ( 1 - italic_Œ∫ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ italic_L ( 2 + | 1 + italic_Œ≥ | italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG , italic_Œ∫ > 1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 1 + 4 italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + | 1 + italic_Œ≥ | ( italic_Œ∫ + 2 italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG end_ARG ,

and run Algorithm 3 for TùëáTitalic_T iterations. Then,

1T‚àët=0Tùîº‚à•‚àáF(ùê±t)‚à•2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum^{T}_{t=0}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left\lVert% \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E ‚à• ‚àá italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§2‚Å¢(F‚Å¢(ùê±0)+Œ≤‚Å¢‚à•‚àáF‚Å¢(ùê±0)‚à•2‚àíF‚ãÜ)C1‚Å¢Œ∑‚Å¢Tabsent2ùêπsubscriptùê±0ùõΩsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àáùêπsubscriptùê±02superscriptùêπ‚ãÜsubscriptùê∂1ùúÇùëá\displaystyle\leq\frac{2(F(\mathbf{x}_{0})+\beta\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{x}% _{0})\right\rVert^{2}-F^{\star})}{C_{1}\eta T}‚â§ divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_Œ≤ ‚à• ‚àá italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÜ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ italic_T end_ARG
+2‚Å¢(Œ≤+Œ∑2‚Å¢L)‚Å¢Œ∫2C1‚Å¢Œ∑‚Å¢(\xwedit‚Å¢(2+|1+Œ≥|)‚Å¢œÉSGD2B+d‚Å¢œÉDP2),2ùõΩsuperscriptùúÇ2ùêøsuperscriptùúÖ2subscriptùê∂1ùúÇ\xwedit21ùõæsubscriptsuperscriptùúé2SGDùêµùëësubscriptsuperscriptùúé2DP\displaystyle\quad+\frac{2(\beta+\eta^{2}L)\kappa^{2}}{C_{1}\eta}\left(\frac{% \xwedit{(2+\left\lvert 1+\gamma\right\rvert)}\sigma^{2}_{\mathrm{SGD}}}{B}+d% \sigma^{2}_{\mathrm{DP}}\right),+ divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_Œ≤ + italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L ) italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ end_ARG ( divide start_ARG ( 2 + | 1 + italic_Œ≥ | ) italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_SGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG + italic_d italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_DP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (8)

where CŒ≥=1+4‚Å¢(2+1/Œ∫+|1+Œ≥|)Œ≥2subscriptùê∂ùõæ1421ùúÖ1ùõæsuperscriptùõæ2C_{\gamma}=1+\frac{4(2+1/\kappa+\left\lvert 1+\gamma\right\rvert)}{\gamma^{2}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 + divide start_ARG 4 ( 2 + 1 / italic_Œ∫ + | 1 + italic_Œ≥ | ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG, C1=(1+Œ∫‚àí2‚Å¢Œ∑‚Å¢L)‚àí4‚Å¢(Œ≤+Œ∑2‚Å¢L)‚Å¢(1‚àíŒ∫)2‚Å¢L2‚Å¢Œ∑‚Å¢\xwedit‚Å¢(2+|1+Œ≥|‚Å¢CŒ≥)>0,subscriptùê∂11ùúÖ2ùúÇùêø4ùõΩsuperscriptùúÇ2ùêøsuperscript1ùúÖ2superscriptùêø2ùúÇ\xwedit21ùõæsubscriptùê∂ùõæ0C_{1}=(1+\kappa-2\eta L)-4(\beta+\eta^{2}L)(1-\kappa)^{2}L^{2}\eta\xwedit{% \left(2+\left\lvert 1+\gamma\right\rvert C_{\gamma}\right)}>0,italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 + italic_Œ∫ -
